text: Department of Interior’s “Christmas Present” to the American Public: Lockup More Federal Land (January
label: HH1

text: During the “lame duck” session of the 111th Congress, Democratic members of the U.S. Senate
label: BODY

text: had their sights set on passing yet another omnibus public lands bill to designate thousands of
label: BODY

text: acres of wilderness and enact other restrictions on federal land-use.  Thankfully, this effort was
label: BODY

text: met with strong resistance by Senate conservatives and was quickly dropped before Congress
label: BODY

text: adjourned on December 22
label: BODY

text: nd.  However, in what
label: BODY

text: appears to be a consolation prize to the environmental activist community and its supporters,
label: BODY

text: upon Congress’ adjournment Department of the Interior Secretary Salazar released
label: BODY

text: Secretarial Order #3310
label: BODY

text: , which instructs the federal Bureau of Land Management (BLM) to identify and designate BLM
label: BODY

text: lands with wilderness characteristics as “Wild Lands.”
label: BODY

text: By designating “Wild Lands” through land-use planning, this order represents a deliberate
label: BODY

text: end-run around the authority of Congress to designate lands as wilderness.  While I have long
label: BODY

text: opposed wilderness designations under any circumstances due to their extreme restrictions on
label: BODY

text: beneficial and economic use of our federal lands, as well as the management restrictions that
label: BODY

text: inhibit local efforts to address the growing threat of wildfires, I also believe that those decisions
label: BODY

text: are best made through open debate and a vote by the Congress instead of through a backdoor
label: BODY

text: process that is solely at the discretion of a federal agency.  Moreover, as the Obama
label: BODY

text: Administration continues to claim that it has no plans to designate national monuments in
label: BODY

text: response to a leaked  memo  describing potential monument sites (including two within our
label: BODY

text: Northern California Congressional District), this latest action further undermines their credibility.
label: BODY

text: Instead, these statements simply reinforce the Administration’s “lock it up” agenda with respect
label: BODY

text: to multiple-use of federal lands.  As the 112
label: BODY

text: th Congress convenes
label: BODY

text: with an emboldened conservative majority, I will pursue whatever means possible to prevent
label: BODY

text: this Secretarial Order or any other policy from further restricting recreation, forest management,
label: BODY

text: mining, grazing, and other valuable uses of our public lands in Northern California.
label: BODY
